elements.text: One Day On Our Blue Planet … in the Savannah
One Day On Our Blue Planet … In the Savannah
This informational text shows one full day in a lion cub’s home: the African Savannah. There are many opportunities to count animals and use location words to describe the lion’s world.

Have 3 children stand up. Lead the class in counting each one. Then, hold up 3 fingers and count. Show children that both counts are 3! Repeat with other numbers up to 10.
To the tune of “Five Little Ducks:”
Five little cubs went out one dayOver the savannah and far awayFather lion said roar, roar, roarFour little cubs came back for more!
This week we are going to read
One Day On Our Blue Planet … in the Savannah
Lala loves all sorts of books. She especially loves informational texts like this one, with so many pictures of animals to count!
There is a question I want you to think about as we read: What is one animal that lives in a savannah?
Read the main text and then review the
on the inside of the front and back covers.
Focus on Counting: Pause to have children count each animal on the page with 1:1 correspondence.
We are going to read about a lion cub that lives on the African Savannah. What is it like on the savannah?
How many birds can you count on this page? Where do you think these birds live?
The place where an animal lives and grows best is called its
How many birds do you see on this page? How many lions do you see? Is that the same number of animals? How can you tell?
I see one cub biting another cub’s ear. That looks like it hurts!
It’s important to play with friends gently so no one gets hurt. How can you stop and think while you play to make sure your friends are also having fun?
These lions are going to stay in the bushes for the night. How many lions are staying in the bushes?
Let’s talk about the guiding question: What is one animal that lives in a savannah?
. Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses to the guiding question.
Write and read aloud short number sentences about the African Savannah as children watch and listen.
What animal with stripes did we see living in the savannah?
We saw a zebra living in the savannah.
Which savannah animal would you like to learn more about? Why?

In order to count a set of items, children need to know the number words in order, matching one number word to one item while counting, and be able to keep track of which items have been counted. When you count with children, keep a finger on each item as it is counted to demonstrate clearly how to count accurately.
Share the Mind Builder: Resist Impulses

When you resist impulses, you are able to stop and think before you do something. You might want to eat a cookie without permission, but you know you will get in trouble if you do! You can stop and think of other ways to have fun instead. Informational texts are a great way to learn about how others control their impulses and what you can do to control your own.
Today we are going to revisit
One Day On Our Blue Planet … in the Savannah
by Ella Bailey to look closer and learn more about the animals’ behavior.
Sometimes Clifford wants to skip right to the end of a book. But he stops himself. He knows he won’t learn all the information that way!
Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
Let’s reread and talk about some pages of the book to see how we can use our resist impulses Mind Builder.
Use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions.
The cub on this page looks excited to see the world! But he steps slowly out of the den. Why doesn’t he run out to play?
When have you had to stop and think before running out to play?
The cub has lots of cousins! Let’s count them.
Ask a child to come up and point to each cousin, counting them one at a time.
Roaring loudly is part of a lion’s behavior.
Sometimes it’s good to be loud! But sometimes it’s better to be quiet. What do we do when we need to be quiet, even if we really want to be loud?
So many animals drink from the river! Why is it important to keep the river clean? What can you do to help keep nature clean?
Let’s count the number of mother lions on this page.
Now, let’s count the number of clouds.
Ask a child to point to each lion and cloud while counting them.
Are there as many clouds as lionesses? How can you tell?

If space and weather permit, bring children outside or into a larger room to play a game of ”Red Light, Green Light.” After you come back inside, discuss how it felt when children heard “red light.” Was it difficult for them to resist their impulse to keep running?
Transcribe children’s speech as they tell number stories about animals in the African Savannah.

Impulse control is an important part of acting responsibly toward ourselves and others. Support children’s impulse control by looking for teachable moments in everyday life. When children find ways to stop and think about their actions, they build the executive function skills needed to develop logical thinking and responsibility. (Diamond, 2006)
Introduce location words. Hold your hand high and say,
My hand is above my head.
Hold your hand beneath your chin and say,
My hand is under my head.
Move Lala the Lizard puppet to different places in the room. Ask children to describe where the puppet is, using
Today we are going to reread the book
One Day On Our Blue Planet … in the Savannah
Lala loves this informational book. There are so many animals in the savannah to learn about!
We are going to learn more about the African Savannah. As we read today, I want you to think about this guiding question: What do lions do in the savannah?
Facilitate back-and-forth conversations with children to extend language.
Who can come up and point to the bird on this page? This bird is above the lion cub!
The cub is chasing his mother’s tail. Do you think mom likes that?
Sometimes adults aren’t ready to play. How can you tell whether adults are ready to play? What can you do if you want to play, but an adult doesn’t?
Let’s count the lions one by one.
These lions are relaxing under the tree.
Point to the sun on page 14.
What is this orange circle? It’s the sun! It looks like the sun is going down. What time of day is it in the picture? How can you tell?
What time of day is it now? What can you see in the sky?
Is the owl flying above or under the lions?
. Where is the lion cub sleeping if he is under the moon? Is he high in the sky, or down on the ground? Show me with your hands!
Did you listen and remember as we read the story today? What do lions do in the savannah?
. Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses to the guiding question.
Share a pen with children as you work together to write about where animals live in the African Savannah.
How do lions find food in the savannah?
If you lived in the savannah, what would you like to do?

Practicing with location words not only develops spatial awareness, but also prepares children to follow directions later in life. In kindergarten classrooms, children are often told to put things under a table or stand behind a line. If children do not know directional language, misunderstandings can lead to perceived behavior issues.
Revisit and discuss where animals live. Have children use location words to describe what they remember about the places animals live and play in the savannah.
Make a list of five visible classroom items. Ask children to tell the location of each item using positional words.
Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
. It is an informational poster full of facts about an animal habitat called a
One Day On Our Blue Planet … in the Savannah
each focus on where animals live. Let’s look for connections between the two as we read.
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about this week’s question:
What is it like where animals live?
Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, stopping to ask these questions. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to respond.
The pond is a different habitat than the savannah. But many animals still share the water!
How can we stop and think to make sure we are sharing our space well with everyone?
Let’s point to the fish as we count them. What animals are above the fish?
Where is the bird? What animal is under it?
I see a grasshopper’s long legs! What animal is standing next to it?
Let’s count the number of worms in the picture.
Let’s count the number of rabbits.
Are there the same number of rabbits as there are worms? How can you tell?
Play another round of “Simon Says.” As “Simon,” give children directions using location words. For example:
Simon says pretend to dig under the ground. Simon says stand next to me.
Remind children to stop and think before following your instructions.
Provide a writing prompt about animal homes and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

Location words are prepositions, which can be particularly difficult for multilingual learners to grasp. Help children visualize the meanings of location words by drawing a picture that represents each concept. For example, draw a bird under a tree. Then, draw the bird flying above the tree. Connect the words to the illustrations by pointing to each as you discuss.
Name animals children will recognize from this week’s texts: lion, duck, zebra, giraffe, rabbit, and deer. For each animal, ask children,
Does this animal live in the savannah or at the pond?
Encourage children to act like the animal in its habitat as they sort.
One Day On Our Blue Planet … in the Savannah
Who remembers if this book tells us a story or teaches information?
We have learned about many places where animals live. When we read today, I want you to think about this question:
What is one way a lion cub’s home is similar to your home?
Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts.
Let’s pretend to sneak slowly from our secret den, like the lion cub!
Why is it important to stop and think before we leave our home? What could we forget, or need to do first?
Let’s all roar loudly, like a lion!
Where is the cub in this picture? Is he above, under, or next to his dad?
What do you see above the father lion in this picture? Do you remember what the animal in the tree is called?
Let’s all pretend to climb and play like monkeys!
What animal is next to the lioness? That animal is her prey.
Let’s point to all of the birds flying above the savannah. Where is the hippopotamus?
What other animals do you see?
Remind children of the guiding question:
What is one way a lion cub’s home is similar to your home?
Use Equity Sticks to ask children to share their responses to the guiding question.
Lion cubs share their home with their family.
Lion families feed their cubs at home.
Lion cubs play at home with their friends.
Invite children to draw or write about animal homes and share their work.
What do lion cubs do with their friends at home?
Lion cubs like to play with their friends.
What is one way a lion cub’s home is different from your home?

The ability to mentally hold and use information is a critical preschool skill. Working memory skills predict math and reading scores, and are more strongly associated with school readiness than IQ! An essential way to teach these skills is through daily play. This way, children are continually supported and challenged as they progress.
